title: The Presentation of Cerebellar Disease in Vestibular Testing of an Adult Patient
chief_complaint: I get dizzy if I turn too suddenly and if I change position too quickly.

problem_summary.onset: Lifelong history of imbalance; recent exacerbation/evaluation following mTBI and falls.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Mild short and long term memory loss, slow ambulation, headaches, diplopia, depression, gait ataxia, chronic lower back pain.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Falls, difficulty with quick turns or position changes.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is cooperative and motivated; seeking to rule out peripheral vestibular disease.

history.present_illness: Patient referred by fall prevention/mTBI team for comprehensive vestibular assessment. Initial working diagnosis was postural instability secondary to BPPV.
history.medical_psych_history: History of alcohol and tobacco dependence, multiple closed fractures from MVAs, hypothyroidism, depression, mood disorder. Recent diagnosis of rostral vermis syndrome (cerebellar disease) secondary to alcohol abuse.
history.prior_management: Screened by fall prevention and mTBI team.
history.patient_goals: Rule out peripheral vestibular system disease.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Assessments are well within normal limits bilaterally.

tests.name: Computerized Dynamic Posturography (CDP)
tests.key_findings: Motor Control (MC) composite within normal limits but with rightward weight symmetry. Sensory Organization Test (SOT) abnormal with falls in vestibular-dependent conditions (5 and 6).

tests.name: Rotary Chair Testing
tests.key_findings: Normal Sinusoidal Harmonic Acceleration (SHA) and VOR gain. Abnormal Visual Fixation Suppression (VFX) with high failure gains. Step velocity low normal.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Oculomotor
tests.key_findings: Central signs present: Spontaneous up-beating nystagmus. Direction-changing and rebounding gaze-evoked nystagmus. Saccades showed mild inaccuracies (undershoot). Pursuit showed 'cogwheeling' and low gain (especially at 0.40 Hz). Horizontal OKN essentially absent.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Caloric
tests.key_findings: Bithermal open-water calorics were clinically normal for labyrinthine function (no significant weakness), but showed failure of visual fixation suppression.

tests.name: VEMPs
tests.key_findings: Cervical and ocular vestibular evoked myogenic potentials were without repeatable waveforms.

history.present_illness: Follow-up to rule out progressive disorder.

tests.name: Comprehensive Vestibular Assessment (Repeat)
tests.key_findings: Results equivalent to initial exam. Saccadic inaccuracies improved to marginally normal but remained asymmetric (undershooting left). Other findings (abnormal fixation suppression, poor OKN) remained unchanged.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing and normal peripheral vestibular function (normal caloric and rotary chair phase/gain). However, there are significant central vestibular findings consistent with a caudal (posterior) cerebellar syndrome. These include failure of visual fixation suppression, direction-changing and rebound gaze-evoked nystagmus, impaired pursuit, and absent optokinetic nystagmus. Functional balance is compromised in vestibular-dependent conditions due to the inability to utilize vestibular cues effectively.
counseling_points: Your inner ear balance sensors (peripheral system) are working normally.
The difficulty lies in the brain's central processing center (cerebellum), which is having trouble integrating the balance signals.
This explains why you feel dizzy with quick turns or position changes, as your brain cannot suppress or process the motion signals quickly enough.
Safety is a priority; use caution when turning or changing positions to prevent falls.
Physical therapy for balance rehabilitation is recommended to help you develop strategies to manage these symptoms.
notes_for_actor: Portray a cooperative and motivated patient who is nevertheless frustrated by a lifelong history of imbalance.
You have a history of alcohol abuse and mTBI, but you are currently alert and trying to find answers.
When describing your dizziness, emphasize that it is triggered by sudden turns or position changes.
You do not have hearing loss, so you can communicate normally without asking for repetition.
